newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Kredietbank up on renewed merger talk.
newsitem.headline: Kredietbank up on renewed merger talk.

text.p: Shares in Belgian Kredietbank NV rose more than two percent on the Brussels bourse Wednesday on renewed talk of merger plans with another Belgian bank, Cera, as a precursor to cooperation with Dutch Rabobank.
At 0830 GMT KB was up 300 francs, or 1.9 percent, at 16,100 francs after earlier touching 16,175.
"(KB and Cera) are no longer denying the reports," one trader said. He said the market was expecting a full merger or close cooperation between the two Belgian banks.
There were doubts however about a partnership with Rabobank, he added.
One trader said the rumours of a deal with Cera, which erupted early June, had been virtually discounted in KB's share price and that upward potential was limited.
"On the contrary, (KB) will slide if it would be called off," he said.

KB was at 14,850 francs when first reports of talks with Cera and Rabobank emerged. The Dutch co-operative bank has since said it could undertake a joint venture with KB and Cera but ruled out a merger with them.
Belgian financial daily L'Echo quoted the chairman of Belgian holding company Almanij, Jan Huyghebaert, as saying there was a certain logic to an alliance with Cera.
L'Echo quoted him as saying there would be no important announcements before September-October.
A Cera Bank spokesman had no comment on the reports.
"It is clear that we have thought of Cera, but there is no news to report, or no news that is ripe enough to be news," a KB spokesman was quoted as saying.
